_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Exhaust ventilation system, detection and alarm system, manual remote container valve closers.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Upgraded to state of the art chlorine alarms; new ventilation systems
_prev_prog_3.Description: There are three basic types of controls available to prevent and mitigate personnel injuries.  The first line of defense is prevention.  PGDP employees use both safety equipment and administrative controls to reduce the probability of a chlorine release.  These controls range from installation of vacuum regulators to frequent replacement of container valves.  The second type of control is one that mitigates the release once it has occurred.  These controls include the lazy rods, respirators, ventilation systems, and the chlorine detection and alarm systems that, either directly or indirectly, inititate emergency response actions.  The third method of controlling personnel injuries is to limit exposure time.  This is accomplished by providing alarms for personnel inside and outside the facility, adequate egress, and eyewash/safety showers within a reasonable distance from the chlorine source.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE PADUCAH GASEOUS DIFFUSION PLANT

                                                                           EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


1.   INTRODUCTION

The United States Enrichment Corporation (USEC) has prepared a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant (PGDP).  The RMP is in accordance with the requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  The PGDP plant is subject to Process Safety Management (PSM) and RMP requirements.

2.   MANAGEMENT AND ORGANIZATION

USEC is committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and safety of the workers and the public, and protects the environment.  In order to meet these commitments, USEC has issued an operations policy manual which states, in part:  USEC is ultimately responsible for, and is committed to, safe operations,  maintenance, design, fabrication, and testing of the Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant and is committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and safety of workers and the public, protects the environment, and provides for the common defense and security.

Program and staff organizations are established for safety, safeguards and quality, and environmental, safety, and health with sufficient resources to support the line organization in safe operation of the plant.

3.   GENERAL DESCRIPTION

3.1  Facility Description

PGDP enriches uranium using the gaseous diffusion process.  PGDP is located on a 3,425-acre site, of which 748 acres are within the controlled plant security fence.  The entire facility is owned by the United States Department of Energy (DOE).  

USEC leases and operates a  portion of the plant. The portion of PGDP leased by USEC contains more than 115 buildings with a total floor space of about 8 million square feet.  Four large enrichment process buildings constitute approximately 75 percent of the plants' total floor space.  There are also cooling towers, electrica

l switchyards, and several support operations structures, including sewage and liquid effluent treatment plants, decontamination and recovery operations, coal and ash-handling facilities, water treatment facilities, steam plant, maintenance operations, laboratories, fluorine facilities, and air plants.

Buildings, facilities, and areas not leased by USEC are owned and operated by DOE.

This RMP applies only to facilities leased by USEC.

3.2  Regulated Substances

Chlorine is the only substance listed in 40 CFR 68.130 which is present in quantities exceeding the threshold quantity.  Chlorine is managed in accordance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 PSM program.

3.3  Use of Regulated Substances

Raw water is taken from the Ohio River, treated and supplied to PGDP for numerous uses.  A portion of the water is filtered and post-disinfected, using chlorine, and used to supply potable water, fire system water, cooling water, and other uses.  Raw water treatment takes place at the C-611 Water Treatment Plant which is located to the west of the plant.  Chlorine is used at two locations at C-611.  One location has two containers with one container connected to the manifold system, and one location with four containers of which two are connected to the manifold system at any time.

A portion of the water treated at C-611 is provided to the recirculating cooling water (RCW) system.  This system provides cooling water to the enrichment process.  RCW is treated with chlorine, via chlorinators in four RCW pump houses,  to control the growth of microorganisms in the RCW system.  Two pump houses have two 1-ton containers with one container connected to the manifold system, and two pump houses have four 1-ton containers of which two are connected to the manifold system at any time.

Chlorine is also stored in 1-ton containers at a storage yard near the western boundary of the fenced area and at a storage yard near the C-611 facility. 

4.   FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Ther

e have been no major releases of chlorine involving injury to site workers,  environmental effects, or any impact to the public within the past five years.  Chlorine releases have been limited to small leaks from manifolds and manifold connections.

5.   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Chemical safety at PGDP consists of the integration of environmental, safety, and health management systems to address chemical safety.  Chemical safety controls are designed to mitigate the adverse affects of the toxic materials used in the enrichment process to workers, the public, and the environment.  To achieve this objective, safety analyses, process hazard analyses, and industrial hygiene and safety programs are utilized.

5.1  Systems

All chlorine feed facilities are equipped with container-mounted vacuum regulators which reduce the pressure of the chlorine from the vapor pressure of the liquid chlorine in the container to a partial vacuum.  Loss of vacuum for any reason causes the vacuum-regulating valve to close the gas supply, minimizing the release in the event of a break in the manifold.

All chlorine feed facilities are equipped with chlorine detectors which provide alarms to plant personnel in the event of a release.

Manually operated, remote valve closing rods are administratively required to be in place on the stem of open 1-ton chlorine container valves.  These valves can be operated from outside of the chlorinator rooms in the event of a release from the manifold system.

5.2  Procedures

Plant procedures are prepared in accordance with the requirements of a formal procedure system.  The procedure program includes the development, review and approval, revision process, distribution, and procedure configuration management.  Specific procedures for the operation and maintenance of chlorine systems and the handling of chlorine cylinders are managed within this procedure system.

5.3  Training

Employee training is conducted by a dedicated training organization

.  Personnel who operate, maintain, manage, handle, and have emergency response duties for chemicals covered by PSM are adequately trained for the particular chemical system or related activity.

If activities performed by non-PGDP personnel (contractor personnel) interface with chemical systems, appropriate training and guidance is required.  PGDP representatives provide guidance for training and job performance.

5.4  Maintenance and Inspection

The Engineering group, in conjunction with the specific facility maintenance organizations and the manufacturer's recommendations, develops maintenance and inspection requirements and criteria for chemical systems.  These chemical safety requirements are based on PSM program requirements for the particular system.

Maintenance of chemical systems is performed in accordance with the facility maintenance programs that include the PSM Mechanical Integrity program for systems covered under PSM.

Maintenance work packages are prepared to provide the necessary technical and safety guidance for maintenance activities.

5.5  Preventive Maintenance

Manufacturer's recommendations are used as guides for preventive maintenance on specific chemical systems and equipment.  Equipment installed or maintenance services provided by contractors for chemical systems are tested and inspected by the contractor as required by the contract for that project.  PGDP personnel also perform independent inspection and testing.

5.6  Quality Considerations

Independent overview of maintenance activities on chemical hardware is addressed by the Quality Assurance and Configuration Management programs, as applicable.  These independent programs include:
  
Procurement Quality Requirements
Construction Inspection
Testing and Pre-Operational Inspection
Pressure Vessel Inspection
Crane Inspection
Operational Readiness Review and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs
Plant Operations Review Committee

5.7  Configuration Management (CM)

The CM program is applica

ble to chemical systems.  The plant CM Program includes an organizational structure and administrative process and controls to ensure that accurate, current design documentation is maintained that matches the plant physical configuration.

In accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119(i), a pre-startup safety review is performed for new or modified facilities when the change is significant enough to require a change to process safety information.  The pre-startup safety review is an independent review to address the readiness of the system hardware, associated hazard controls, personnel (including required training), and procedures.  If the change does not require a change to process safety information, a pre-startup safety review is not performed.

6.   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

PGDP maintains a written Emergency Plan.  The Emergency Management organization is responsible for maintaining and updating the plan as appropriate.

6.1  Organization

The Emergency Response Organization (ERO) is responsible for taking immediate mitigative and corrective actions to minimize the consequences of an incident involving the release of toxic substances (including chlorine) to workers, public health and safety, and the environment.  The ERO is staffed with trained personnel who respond to events and are required to participate in formal training, drills, and exercises.

The ERO includes the Plant Emergency Squad consisting of the following:

Plant Shift Superintendent (PSS)
Police operations
Fire Services
Operating shift, nonsupervisory, supervisory, and specialist personnel

The site ERO is staffed 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  The  on-duty PSS, the senior manager on shift, is responsible for the implementation of the emergency plan.

6.2  ERO Actions

In the event of an emergency, such as a chlorine release, the PSS takes the following actions:

  Takes actions to ensure the safety of plant personnel and the general public
  Takes actions to ensure safe operations/activities of the pl

ant
  Classifies the emergency and makes required notifications, if necessary
  Performs assessment actions
  Performs any other emergency actions as appropriate

6.3  Emergency Response Equipment

Emergency equipment at PGDP includes detectors and alarms, communications equipment, personnel protection equipment and spill/release containment and cleanup equipment.  Container patches and plugs specifically designed for use on the types of chlorine containers used at  PGDP are available to the Plant Emergency Squad.

6.4  Training

Personnel assigned to the ERO are required to satisfactorily complete an initial training program prior to assignment.  ERO personnel are trained to respond to hazardous material emergencies.  Required continuing or refresher training for hazardous material emergency response is conducted annually.

The formal training program includes classroom type training (lectures and seminars), practical applications (tabletop drills, functional drills, and exercises), and self-study programs developed for ERO and support personnel.

6.5  Drills

Drills involving hazardous material response are conducted annually for the Plant Emergency Squad on each shift.  PGDP participates biennially in an Emergency Management Exercise which involves a number of off-site organizations.

6.6  Public Warning System

The public warning system, consisting of outdoor warning sirens and emergency alert systems announcements, is used to provide emergency notification.  Operations testing of the public warning system sirens is conducted monthly.

6.7  Coordination With Off-Site Organizations

Mutual aid agreements, memorandums of understanding, and letters of assistance have been entered into with off-site groups to provide assistance in the event of an emergency.  These support services encompass areas such as medical assistance, fire control, evacuation, ambulance services, and law enforcement.

The Emergency Management organization coordinates required emergency plannin

g activities with local and state agencies including the Kentucky Division of Emergency Management and the Paducah-McCracken County Disaster and Emergency Services.  Emergency planning is also coordinated with DOE.

7.   RMP ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE

* See Attached File
